title: Asymmetry
intent: Break false symmetry to reduce complexity, cost, or risk by assigning different roles or properties to similar-looking parts.

triz_principle.name: Asymmetry
triz_principle.definition: Replace symmetrical structures or interactions with asymmetrical ones where roles and responsibilities differ.

problem_understanding.core_contradiction: We want fairness and uniformity, but equal treatment creates inefficiency, duplication, or deadlocks.
problem_understanding.why_this_hurts: Symmetry often hides decision paralysis: everyone waits for everyone else, or the same heavy rules apply where they are not needed.
typical_signals: mirror systems doing the same work
conflicts over ownership because roles are unclear

solution_logic.core_idea: Intentionally assign different roles, authority, or behavior to similar elements.
solution_logic.key_rule: Make responsibility asymmetric even if structure looks similar.
solution_logic.how_it_resolves_the_contradiction: Clear direction replaces negotiation; decisions flow in one direction, reducing coordination cost and risk.

consulting: define a single decision owner instead of consensus bodies
assign one party as rule-setter and others as rule-consumers
software_engineering: unidirectional data flow instead of bidirectional syncing
architecture: event producers vs event consumers (no symmetry)
enterprise_sap: MDG as single source of truth; S/4 as consumer only
asymmetric authorization: create/change vs view-only roles

anti_patterns: pretending symmetry while hiding power elsewhere
mixing symmetric data ownership with asymmetric processes

use_when: coordination cost is higher than execution cost
decisions are slow due to consensus requirements
systems or teams block each other
do_not_use_when: load or responsibility must be evenly distributed for resilience

diagnostic_questions: Where do we require mutual agreement when one owner would be enough?
Who should be the clear authority in this flow?

example.before: Two systems synchronize master data bidirectionally and constantly conflict.
example.after: One system is the authoritative source; the other only consumes updates via one-way replication.
